revision.text:
{{Year nav topic5|1606|music}}
The year '''1606 in [[music]]''' involved some significant events.
== Events == *[[January 5]] – The nuptial [[masque]] ''[[Hymenaei]]'', with music by [[Alfonso Ferrabosco the younger]], is performed in London.
== Publications == *[[Girolamo Montesardo]] – {{Lang-it|Nuova inventione d'intavolatura per sonare li balletti sopra la chitarra spanuola}}, published in [[Florence]], the first printed source of ''alfabeto'' notation for the [[guitar]]
== Classical music == *[[Agostino Agazzari]] – ''Eumelio'' (oratorio)<ref>{{cite book |last=Palisca |first=Claude V. |title=Baroque Music |edition=3rd. |series=Prentice Hall History of Music |origyear=1968 |year=1991 |publisher=[[Prentice Hall]] |isbn=0-13-058496-7 |pages=125 }}</ref> *[[John Cooper (composer)|John Cooper]] – ''Funeral Teares''
== Opera == *[[Andrea Cima]] – ''La Gentile''
== Births == *''date unknown'' **[[William Child]], organist and composer (d. 1697) **[[Johannes Khuen]], poet and composer (d. 1675) **[[Urbán de Vargas]], composer (d. 1656)
== Deaths == *[[January 28]] – [[Guillaume Costeley]], composer (b. c.1530) *[[September 9]] – [[Leonhard Lechner]], composer and music editor (born c. 1553) *''date unknown'' **[[Jan Trojan Turnovský]], composer (born c.1550) **[[Jiří Nigrin]], music publisher *''probable'' – [[Pellegrino Micheli]], violin maker (born c.1530)
== References == <references/>

{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2015}} In the [[music industry]], a '''360 deal''' (from '''360° deal''') is a business relationship between an artist and a music industry company. The company agrees to provide financial and other support for the artist, including direct advances as well as support in marketing, promotion, touring and other areas. In turn, the artist agrees to give the company a percentage of an increased number of their revenue streams, often including sales of recorded music, live performances, publishing and more. This business arrangement is an alternative to the traditional recording contract. In a 360 deal, a company typically provides support to an artist in more areas than covered by a traditional recording contract on the condition of receiving a percentage of revenue from these additional areas. During the first decade of the 21st century, revenues from recorded music fell dramatically and the profit margins traditionally associated with the record industry disappeared. The 360 deal reflects the fact that much of a musician's income now comes from sources other than recorded music, such as live performance and merchandise. ==History== According to [[Jeff Hanson (music executive)|Jeff Hanson]], head of [[Silent Majority Group]], the first new artist 360° deal was created by Hanson along with attorneys Jim Zumwalt and Kent Marcus, and Jim's partner Orville.{{cite web|url=http://www.hitquarters.com/index.php3?page=intrview/opar/intrview_JeffHanson_Interview_Part2.html |title=Interview with Jeff Hanson |publisher=[[HitQuarters]] |date=September 20, 2010 |accessdate=October 4, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101103105151/http://www.hitquarters.com/index.php3?page=intrview%2Fopar%2Fintrview_JeffHanson_Interview_Part2.html |archivedate=November 3, 2010 |deadurl=no }} It was submitted to [[Atlantic Records]] for the rock band [[Paramore]] while Hanson, Marcus and Zumwalt were employed by the label. Hanson has said there was strong resistance to the deal by both label and band and that he had to fight to make it happen, but believes his efforts were vindicated by the band's subsequent success, saying: "How else would a label have been patient enough to put the band on three straight [[Warped Tour]]s and down-streamed the band to [[Fueled by Ramen]] all while losing millions of dollars?" 360 deals have been made by traditional record companies, as in [[Robbie Williams]]'s pioneering deal with [[EMI]] in 2002.{{cite web | url = http://www.cnet.com/news/recording-industry-should-brace-for-more-bad-news/ | title = Recording industry should brace for more bad news | last = Rosso | first = Wayne | publisher = [[Cnet]] | date = January 16, 2008 | accessdate =September 14, 2009 }} They have also been made between artists and promoters, as with [[Live Nation]]'s 2007 deal with [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]]{{cite news | url = http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/21324512/ | title = Madonna announces huge Live Nation deal | author = Associated Press | date = October 16, 2007 }} and 2008 deal with [[Jay-Z]].{{cite news | last=Leeds | first=Jeff | title=In Rapper's $150 Million Deal, New Model for Ailing Business | newspaper = The New York Times | date = April 3, 2008 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/03/arts/music/03jayz.html?sq=Jay-Z+%22Live+Nation%22&scp=1&st=nyt }} ==Criticism== 360° deals have attracted criticism from various quarters. Panos Panay, CEO of online music platform Sonicbids, has said:
"If you want to find out the future of 360° deals, look at Motown in the late 60s. Motown was the pioneer of a 360° deal ... They owned your likeness, your touring, publishing, record royalties, told you what to wear, told you how to walk … It made for great entertainment but if you look at every one of those artists, what happened? Sooner or later they said, 'I’m not going to go on the road for 200 shows because you tell me so. I’m an artist! I’m a creative person!' Eventually all these artists left ... There’s two things we know about creativity: you can’t force it and you can’t really control it."{{cite web |url=http://www.hitquarters.com/index.php3?page=intrview/opar/intrview_Panos_Panay_Interview.html |title=Interview With Panos Panay |publisher=[[HitQuarters]]|date=July 5, 2010 |accessdate=May 9, 2011}}
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} [[Category:Music industry]]

{{Infobox film | name = A Child Is Born | image = A Child Is Born poster.jpg | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Lloyd Bacon]] | producer = [[Samuel Bischoff]] | screenplay = [[Robert Rossen]] | starring = [[Geraldine Fitzgerald]]
[[Jeffrey Lynn]]
[[Gladys George]]
[[Gale Page]]
[[Spring Byington]]
[[Johnnie Davis]] | music = [[Heinz Roemheld]] | cinematography = [[Charles Rosher]] | editing = Jack Killifer | studio = [[Warner Bros.]] | distributor = Warner Bros. | released = {{Film date|1939|12|7}} | runtime = 79 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''A Child Is Born''''' is a 1939 American [[drama film]] directed by [[Lloyd Bacon]] and written by [[Robert Rossen]]. The film stars [[Geraldine Fitzgerald]], [[Jeffrey Lynn]], [[Gladys George]], [[Gale Page]], [[Spring Byington]] and [[Johnnie Davis]]. The film was released by [[Warner Bros.]] on December 17, 1939.{{cite web|url=http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/3334/A-Child-Is-Born/ |title=A Child Is Born (1940) - Overview |publisher=TCM.com |date= |accessdate=2015-07-24}}{{cite web|last=Nugent |first=Frank S. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=980de2da103ee23abc4952dfb766838b659ede |title=Movie Review - A Child Is Born - THE SCREEN; The Maternity Ward Drama, 'Life Begins,' Is Revived by the Warners as 'A Child Is Born' at the Criterion |publisher=NYTimes.com |date=1940-01-11 |accessdate=2015-07-24}} ==Plot== {{Expand section|date=July 2015}} == Cast == *[[Geraldine Fitzgerald]] as Grace Sutton *[[Jeffrey Lynn]] as Jed Sutton *[[Gladys George]] as Florette *[[Gale Page]] as Miss Bowers *[[Spring Byington]] as Mrs. West *[[Johnnie Davis]] as Ringer Banks *[[Henry O'Neill]] as Dr. Lee *[[John Litel]] as Dr. Brett *[[Gloria Holden]] as Mrs. Kempner *[[Johnny Downs]] as Johnny Norton *[[Eve Arden]] as Miss Pinty *[[Fay Helm]] as The Woman *[[Louis Jean Heydt]] as Mr. Kempner *[[Nanette Fabray]] as Gladys Norton *Jean Sharon as Mrs. Banks *[[Hobart Cavanaugh]] as Mr. West *[[George Irving (American actor)|George Irving]] as Dr. Cramm *[[Nella Walker]] as Mrs. Twitchell *[[Winifred Harris]] as Mrs. Holt == Censorship == Numerous regional censor boards heavily edited or banned the film because they believed its discussions of childbirth would frighten women away from pursuing motherhood. British Columbia rejected the film because, "The showing of this picture would have the effect of creating a fear in the minds of expectant mothers."{{Cite journal|last=Kirby|first=David A.|author-link=David A. Kirby|date=September 2017|title=Regulating cinematic stories about reproduction: pregnancy, childbirth, abortion and movie censorship in the US, 1930–1958|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/british-journal-for-the-history-of-science/article/regulating-cinematic-stories-about-reproduction-pregnancy-childbirth-abortion-and-movie-censorship-in-the-us-19301958/2A1AA5620E20D7E46CE14837999896D2/core-reader|journal=The British Journal for the History of Science|language=en|volume=50|issue=3|pages=451–472|doi=10.1017/S0007087417000814|issn=0007-0874|via=}} == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * {{IMDb title|0032333|A Child Is Born}} * {{tcmdb title|3334|A Child Is Born}} {{Lloyd Bacon}} {{Robert Rossen}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Child Is Born}} [[Category:1939 films]] [[Category:1930s drama films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American black-and-white films]] [[Category:American drama films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films directed by Lloyd Bacon]] [[Category:Hospital films]] [[Category:Pregnancy films]] [[Category:Warner Bros. films]] [[Category:Films scored by Heinz Roemheld]] {{1930s-drama-film-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Pietro Perugino cat20.jpg | title= Agony in the Garden | artist=[[Pietro Perugino]] | year=c. 1483-1493 | medium=[[Oil painting|Oil on panel]] | height_metric=166 | width_metric=171 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city=[[Florence]] | museum=[[Uffizi Gallery]] }} '''''Agony in the Garden''''' is a painting by the Italian Renaissance artist [[Pietro Perugino]], executed around 1483-1493, and housed in the [[Uffizi Gallery]], [[Florence]].
==History== The work was painted for the church of the convent of San Giusto alle mura together with the ''[[Pietà (Pietro Perugino)|Pietà]]'' and a ''[[Crucifixion (Perugino)|Crucifixion]]''. Renaissance art biographer [[Giorgio Vasari]] saw them in side altars of the church of San Giovanni Battista alla Calza, after the original location had been destroyed during the [[Siege of Florence (1529–1530)|Siege of Florence]] in 1529. It was moved to the Uffizi in the 20th century.
The dating of the work is disputed: it varies from 1482, the year of Perugino's return from Rome, to a slightly later period, although before the end of the century, when the artist started to use only line oil, which in these works is used only at an experimental level.
The painting was restored in 1998. ==Description==
Christ is portrayed in center of the panel above a clear sky, kneeling in the [[Garden of Gethsemane]] and receiving by an angel a divine chalice. His figure forms a triangle with the three sleeping apostles at the bottom (from the left, [[John the Apostle|John]], [[Saint Peter|Peter]] and [[James, son of Zebedee|James]]); the triangle is connected to the painting's sides by the symmetrical line of the hills. Behind Jesus is a lake landscape, a typical element of the Italian painting at the time, with a fortified city and an ancient bridge.
At the sides, two groups of soldiers, led by [[Judas Iscariot]], are closing to arrest Jesus.
==Sources==
*{{cite book|first=Vittoria|last=Garibaldi|language=Italian|title=Pittori del Rinascimento|publisher=Scala|chapter=Perugino|location=Florence|year=2004}}
{{Pietro Perugino}}
[[Category:Perugino paintings in the Uffizi]] [[Category:1480s paintings]] [[Category:Christ in the Garden of Gethsemane in art]] [[Category:Paintings depicting Saint Peter]] [[Category:Angels in art]] [[Category:Paintings depicting Judas Iscariot]] [[Category:Paintings depicting John the Apostle]]

{{Infobox manuscript <!----------Name----------> | name = An Leabhar Breac | location = [[Royal Irish Academy]] <!----------Image----------> | image = | width = | caption = <!----------General----------> | Also known as = Speckled Book, Great Book of Dun Doighre | Type = Compilation of [[Irish legends]] | Date = 1408–11 | Place of origin = [[Duniry]] | Language(s) = [[Middle Irish]] and [[Latin]] | Scribe(s) = [[Murchadh Ó Cuindlis]] | Author(s) = | Compiled by = | Illuminated by = | Patron = | Dedicated to = <!----------Form and content----------> | Material = [[Vellum]] | Size = 40.5 cm × 28 cm (16 in × 11 in) | Format = [[Folio]] | Condition = | Script = [[Irish minuscule]] | Contents = | Illumination(s) = | Additions = | Exemplar(s) = | Previously kept = | Discovered = | Other = | below = }} {{Location map | Island of Ireland | relief = yes | width = 250 | caption = Location of Duniry (''Dhún Doighre'') in Ireland | lat_deg = 53.132610 | lon_deg = -8.410544 | label = Duniry }} '''An Leabhar Breac''' ("Speckled Book"), now less commonly '''Leabhar Mór Dúna Doighre''' (The Great Book of Dun Doighre") or possibly erroneously, '''Leabhar Breac Mic Aodhagáin''' ("The Speckled Book of the [[MacEgans]]"),<ref>The Leabhar Breac Mic Aodhagáin is the title of a book cited by [[Geoffrey Keating]] in Book III of ''[[Foras Feasa ar Éirinn]]'', described as an "old book of annals" (''seinleabhar annálach'') and probably now lost. [http://www.isos.dias.ie/master.html?http://www.isos.dias.ie/libraries/RIA/RIA_MS_23_P_16/english/index.html Irish Script on Screen].</ref> is a medieval Irish vellum manuscript containing [[Middle Irish]] and [[Hiberno-Latin]] writings. The manuscript is held in the library of the [[Royal Irish Academy]] in Dublin, where it is catalogued as [[Royal Irish Academy|RIA]] MS '''23 P 16''' or '''1230'''.
It was most probably compiled by [[Murchadh Ó Cuindlis|Murchadh (Riabach) Ó Cuindlis]] of Bally Lough Deacker, at Duniry between the years 1408 and 1411. [[Duniry]] — Dún Daighre, Dún Doighre — in eastern [[Clanricarde]] (now east [[County Galway]]) is situated south-east of the town of [[Loughrea]], and in the medieval era was home to a branch of the bardic Clann [[Mac Aodhagáin]] (the MacEgans), who served as brehons for the O'Connors of Clanricarde.
==History== In the 16th century, the manuscript was in the possession of the Mac Egans of Duniry, hence the older title Leabhar Mór Dúna Doighre. In 1629, when the manuscript was held in the convent of [[Kinalehin Friary|Kinalehin]], County Galway.
It was consulted by [[Mícheál Ó Cléirigh]], brother of the [[Annals of the Four Masters|Four Masters]], who copied pp. 272–7. The book passed into the possession of [[Eamon Ó Ceallaigh]] (Co. Roscommon) in 1732, then of Dr. John O'Brien by 1768 and finally of [[Cornelius O'Daly]] (Mitchelstown, Co. Cork). The [[Royal Irish Academy]] acquired the first volume in 1789, when General [[Charles Vallancey]] purchased it for the academy for 3 [[Guinea (British coin)|guineas]] from Cornelius O'Daly. O'Daly also owned the second volume, which comprises nine leaves, but was unaware that it belonged to the larger volume. In 1789, this volume was acquired by [[Chevalier O'Gorman]], by George Smith of College Green in the next century and by the Academy sometime after 1844. The manuscript is held in the Academy's library in Dublin to this day.<ref>[http://www.isos.dias.ie/master.html?http://www.isos.dias.ie/libraries/RIA/RIA_MS_23_P_16/english/index.html Irish Script on Screen].</ref>
==Description== The manuscript is of a large size, measuring 40.5 cm x 28 cm, which makes it the largest Irish vellum manuscript to have been written by a single scribe.<ref>Royal Irish Academy, [http://www.ria.ie/library+catalogue/word/Leabhar%20Breac.doc "Leabhar Breac"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081118200919/http://www.ria.ie/library%2Bcatalogue/word/Leabhar%20Breac.doc |date=November 18, 2008 }}</ref> It contains 40 [[wikt:folio|folio]]s, which are written in double columns. Capitals are decorated in a simple style, with some letters having been interwoven with zoomorphic patterns and coloured in red, vermilion, yellow and blue. There are two drawings, a flower-like diagram on p. 121 and a drawing of the Crucifixion on p. 166.<ref>See [http://www.isos.dias.ie/master.html?http://www.isos.dias.ie/libraries/RIA/RIA_MS_23_P_16/english/index.html the images at ISOS].</ref>
==Contents== The manuscript consists almost entirely of religious writings in Latin and [[Middle Irish]]. It includes homiletic ''Lives'' of [[Saint Patrick]], [[Saint Columba]], [[Saint Brigid]], [[Saint Cellach]], and [[Martin of Tours|Saint Martin]], the earliest version of ''[[Félire Óengusso]]'' ("Martyrology of [[Óengus Céile Dé|Óengus]]"), the ''Rule of the Céli Dé'', ''[[Aislinge Meic Con Glinne]]'' ("The Vision of Mac Conglinne"), a version of ''[[Fís Adamnáin]]'' ("The Vision of [[Adamnán]]"), ''[[Saltair na Rann]]'', ''Stair Nicomeid'' ("Gospel of Nicodemus"), ''Amra Choluim Chille'', a [[Marian litany]], and various ecclesiastical legends, hymns, catecheses and homilies. Exceptions to the predominantly religious contents are ''[[Sanas Cormaic]]'' ("Cormac's Glossary") and a history of Philip of Macedon and Alexander the Great.<ref>Peters, E. (ed. and tr.). "Die irische Alexandersage." [[ZCP]] 30 (1967): 71–264.</ref>
==Glosses and notes== The numerous notes which Murchadh Ó Cuindlis jotted into the margins afford us a unique glimpse of the circumstances of the writing process. These range from everyday details like a cat straying about or a robin singing in a beautiful voice to a nearby pillage in [[Lorrha]] by a certain Murchad Ua Madagáin. A persistent object of complaint for the writer is the weather, in particular the cold.<ref name="O'Neill, Leabhar Breac.">O'Neill, "Leabhar Breac."</ref> Based on the notes, Tomás Ó Concheanainn has been able to reconstruct the time span in which certain sections had been written. For instance, it took the scribe about 6 weeks to write 35 pages (pp. 141–75), while some parts proved more challenging, such as a column for a poem with interlinear glosses, which cost him a day.<ref name="O'Neill, Leabhar Breac." />
==Footnotes== {{reflist}}
== See also == *[[Irish annals]]
==References== *Welsh, Robert. ''Oxford Concise Companion to Irish Literature''. 1996. {{ISBN|0-19-280080-9}} *O'Neill, Timothy. "Leabhar Breac." In ''Medieval Ireland. An Encyclopedia'', ed. Seán Duffy. New York, 2004. 266-7.
==Sources (with external links)== *Anonymous = Joseph Ó Longáin (fasc) and J.J. Gilbert (ed.). ''Leabhar Breac, the Speckled Book, otherwise styled Leabhar Mór Dúna Doighre, the Great Book of Dun Doighre''. Dublin, 1876. Lithographic [[facsimile]] edition.<ref>[https://archive.org/stream/LeabharBreacV1#page/n5]</ref> *[http://www.isos.dias.ie/master.html?http://www.isos.dias.ie/libraries/RIA/RIA_MS_23_P_16/english/index.html Irish Script on Screen] ([[Dublin Institute for Advanced Studies|DIAS]]): images and description of Leabhar Breac. *Atkinson, Robert (ed. and tr.). ''The Passions and the Homilies from Leabhar Breac: Text, Translation, and Glossary''. Todd Lecture Series II. Dublin, 1887. [http://www.ucc.ie/celt/online/G206000 Edited text available online from CELT]. *''Betha Phatraic'' "Life of St Patrick" (Leabhar Breac pp. 24b-29b), ed. and tr. Whitley Stokes, ''Three Middle-Irish Homilies''. Calcutta, 1877. [http://www.ucc.ie/celt/published/G201009 Text edition] and [http://www.ucc.ie/celt/published/T201009 translation] available online from CELT. *''Rule of the Céli Dé'' (9b-12b), ed. [[E.J. Gwynn]]. In ''The Rule of Tallaght.'' Hermathena 44, Second Suppelement. 1927. *Greene, David and Frank O’Connor (eds. & trs.). ''A golden treasury of Irish poetry, A.D. 600 to 1200''. London: Macmillan, 1967.
==Further reading== *Bernard, J.H. "On the citations from scripture in the Leabhar Breac." ''Transactions of the Royal Irish Academy'' 30 (1893): 321-4. *Egan, J.J. and Egan, M.J. ''History of Clan Egan. The birds of the forest of wisdom.'' Ann Arbor, 1979. 59-67. *Mulchrone, Kathleen et al. ''Catalogue of Irish manuscripts in the Royal Irish Academy''. Dublin, 1943. Fasc. 27. *Ó Concheanainn, Tomás. "The scribe of the Leabhar Breac." ''[[Ériu (journal)|Ériu]]'' 24 (1973): 64-79. *Ritmueller, J. "The Hiberno-Latin Background of the Leabhar Breac Homily "In Cena Domini"." ''Proceedings of the Harvard Celtic Colloquium'' 2 (1982): 1-10. *Haubrichs, Wolfgang. "Die altlateinische Gallicanus-version (Gall.) der Georgslegende und ihr Reflex im 'Leabhar Breac'." In ''Ireland and Europe in the early Middle Ages. Texts and transmission / Irland und Europa im früheren Mittelalter. Texte und Überlieferung'', ed. Próinséas Ní Chatháin and Michael Richter. Dublin: Four Courts, 2002. 170-85.

Catalogue of medieval Irish narratives & literary enumerations] * ''[http://www.ucd.ie/tlh/text/rib.misc.001.text.html The Lebar Brecc Tractate on the Canonical Hours]'', ed. R.I. Best. * ''[http://www.ucd.ie/tlh/text/km.gj.5.12.001.text.html Regula Mochuta Rathin]'', ed. K. Meyer. * ''[http://www.ucd.ie/tlh/text/km.gj.4.38.002.text.html The Mothers’ Lament at the Slaughter of the Innocents]'', ed. K. Meyer. * ''[http://www.ucd.ie/tlh/text/tpon.misc.001.text.html Imchlód Aingel (Aingil Dé dom dín)]'', ed. T.P. O’Nolan. * '' [https://archive.org/stream/diekreuzeslegen00schigoog#page/n7/mode/2up Die Kreuzeslegenden im Leabhar Breac - Inaugural-Dissertaion zur Erlangung de Doctorwuerde]'' (in German) By Gustav Schirmer, St. Gallen, 1886 {{Ancient Irish manuscripts}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox Futurama episode | episode_name = Anthology of Interest II | episode_no = 18 | image = | caption = | prod_code = 3ACV18 | airdate = January 6, 2002 | writer = '''I, Meatbag:'''
[[Lewis Morton]]
'''Raiders of the Lost Arcade:'''
[[David X. Cohen]]
'''Wizzin':'''
Jason Gorbett
Scott Kirby| | director = [[Bret Haaland]] | music = "[[Tom Sawyer (song)|Tom Sawyer]]" by [[Rush (band)|Rush]] | opening_subtitle = Hey [[TiVo]]! Suggest ''this''! | opening_cartoon = "A Close Call" (1929) | season = 3 | prev = [[A Pharaoh to Remember]] | next = [[Roswell That Ends Well]] }} "'''Anthology of Interest II'''" is the 18th episode of ''[[Futurama]]''{{'}}s [[Futurama (season 3)|third season]]. It originally aired on the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox network]] in the United States on January 6, 2002. This episode, as well as the earlier "[[Anthology of Interest I]]", serves to showcase three "imaginary" stories. ==Plot== Professor Farnsworth hauls out his What-If Machine again, fine-tunes it, and the crew takes a look at three alternative realities. ===I, Meatbag=== [[Bender Bending Rodríguez|Bender]] asks what would happen if he were human. The simulation opens with [[Hubert J. Farnsworth|Professor Farnsworth]] announcing that he has invented a process of reverse [[Petrifaction|fossilization]], which can turn robots and machines into organic life-forms. He uses his process on Bender, who is transformed into a human. After a short period of adaptation, Bender's self-control is overwhelmed by his new senses of taste and touch, and goes on a binge of eating, smoking, partying, and drinking alcohol. A week later, at the [[Nobel Prize]] judging, the Professor presents Bender, who has become an overweight blob. The committee initially condemns Farnsworth, but Bender begs them to consider his lifestyle. This inspires the scientists to spend the night in a state of wild [[hedonism]]. The next morning, the hungover committee awards Bender the [[Nobel Prize in Chemistry]], but discover that he died the moment the party began. The "woo!" noises that the partygoers assumed were from Bender were actually caused by air escaping the many folds of fat on his body. The Planet Express crew sadly roll away Bender's corpse. ===Raiders of the Lost Arcade=== [[Philip J. Fry|Fry]] asks to see a world that is more like a video game. As the simulation starts, President of Earth [[Richard Nixon]] is preparing to sign a treaty with Ambassador [[Donkey Kong (character)|Kong]] of planet [[Nintendo 64|Nintenduu 64]]. Ambassador Kong attacks Nixon, and a state of war erupts. Due to his extensive knowledge of video games from the 20th Century, Fry is brought to the [[Military|Mil]][[atari]] headquarters and introduced to General [[Colin Powell|Colin]] [[Pac-Man]]. Before Fry can impart his wisdom to the military, the Nintendians launch an attack on [[Washington, D.C.]], and they are forced into the escape tunnels, which resemble a [[Pac-Man]] board. They emerge outside the Planet Express building, where the Nintendian invaders, led by [[List of recurring characters in Futurama#Lrrr|Lrrr]], are blasting New New York. Fry situates himself at the controls of a rolling [[anti-aircraft artillery]] platform, and begins destroying the alien ships in a manner similar to [[Space Invaders]]. Fry is unable to destroy the final ship, which lands nearby. The invaders emerge and demand "a million allowances worth of quarters" with which to do their laundry. The Earthlings refuse. The invaders suggest they be allowed to throw their laundry in with Earth's as a compromise, and the Earthlings agree. ===Wizzin'=== [[Leela (Futurama)|Leela]] asks what if she found her true home. However, when the lever is pulled to start the simulation, it hits Leela on the head and knocks her unconscious, prompting her to dream a parody of ''[[The Wizard of Oz (1939 film)|The Wizard of Oz]]'' with Leela as [[Dorothy Gale|Dorothy]], Nibbler as [[Toto (Oz)|Toto]], Amy as [[Glinda the Good Witch]], Fry as the [[Scarecrow (Oz)|Scarecrow]], Bender as the [[Tin Woodman|Tin Man]], Zoidberg as the [[Cowardly Lion|Cowardly Lobster]], and Professor Fansworth as [[Wizard of Oz (character)|the Professor of Oz]]. Leela and Nibbler, while riding in the Planet Express ship, are taken by tornado to Oz. The ship's landing gear lands on the Wicked Witch of the East, killing her. Leela takes the witch's magic boots from her corpse and puts them on, since it is hard to find footwear in her size. She asks Amy for help getting back home, and Amy tells her that only The Professor at the Emerald Laboratory can send her home. Leela is joined in her quest by Fry, Bender, and Zoidberg. They all are captured by Wicked Witch [[Mom (Futurama)|Mom]] who asks Leela to be her witch daughter. Leela happily agrees, but when Bender pops opens a celebratory bottle of champagne, the spilled liquid causes Mom to melt into nothing. They resume their journey to the Emerald Laboratory, where The Professor tells Leela to click her boot heels together and wish to be sent back home. Instead, she uses them to become a witch and turns Fry, Bender and The Professor into toads. However, a toilet overflow in the upstairs bathroom (caused by Zoidberg's use of it) leaks through the ceiling and onto Leela, causing her to melt. She wakes up to find Bender splashing water in her face and berates the crew for showing up in her wonderful dream and ruining it. ==Cultural references== ===I, Meatbag=== In a split-second establishing shot of New New York before the Professor's press conference, the towers of the [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]] are seen. This episode aired on January 6, 2002, about 4 months after the towers were destroyed.
The song that Bender becomes infatuated with as a human is "[[Conga (song)|Conga]]" by [[Gloria Estefan]]. The title of the segment is a nod to the [[Isaac Asimov]] collection of short stories ''[[I, Robot]]''. ===Raiders of the Lost Arcade=== [[File:Anthology Of Interest II SpaceInvaders.png|thumb|left|A parody of the game ''[[Space Invaders]]'']] The "Raiders of the Lost Arcade" segment is a "non-stop barrage of game references" with jokes and allusions referencing a wide array of classic video games. The title is a reference to the 1981 film ''[[Raiders of the Lost Ark]]''. The segment starts off with a sequence from ''[[Asteroids (video game)|Asteroids]]''. "Ambassador Kong" is a reference to the arcade game ''[[Donkey Kong (video game)|Donkey Kong]]'', as is [[Italy]]'s ambassador to the U.N. being [[Mario]]. The maze which the characters run through is an homage to both ''[[Pac-Man]]'' and ''[[Ms. Pac-Man]]''. Pac-Man and Ms. Pac-Man both appear in the episode (Pac-Man as General Colin Pacman, and Ms. Pac-Man as his wife/widow). The Nintendians' fleet is composed of ''[[Space Invaders]]'' ships, which move in the same pattern as those in the video game ("Drop down, increase speed, and reverse direction!").{{cite news|url=http://blog.wired.com/games/2007/12/video-games-fut.html| title=Videogames & Futurama, Part 1: Raiders of the Lost Arcade| author= Baker, Chris| date= 2007-12-17| accessdate= 2008-02-02| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080128151750/http://blog.wired.com/games/2007/12/video-games-fut.html| archivedate= 28 January 2008 | deadurl= no| work=Wired}} Fry plays to the accompaniment of a [[cassette tape]] of "[[Tom Sawyer (song)|Tom Sawyer]]" by [[Rush (band)|Rush]]. The planet Nintendu 64 is a reference to the game console [[Nintendo 64]]. When the [[Atari|Milatari]] HQ is first shown, the green tank from ''[[Battlezone (arcade game)|Battlezone]]'' is driving past. When the characters walk through the HQ, they go past doors labelled [[Moon Patrol]] and [[Missile Command]]. As the video game villains (Lrrr, Donkey Kong, a [[Berzerk (arcade game)|Berzerk]] robot, a [[Robotron]] brain, ''[[BurgerTime]]''{{'}}s Mr. Egg, and [[Q*bert]]) exit the landed ship, one character says the phrase "[[All your base are belong to us]]". ===Wizzin'=== The majority of the plot is a direct parody of the 1939 film ''[[The Wizard of Oz (1939 film)|The Wizard of Oz]]'', with Leela taking the place of Dorothy, Amy as the Good Witch of the North, Fry as the Scarecrow, Bender as the Tin Man, Zoidberg as the Cowardly Lion, Professor Farnsworth as the Wizard and Mom as the Wicked Witch of the West. When Leela first exits the spaceship, a parody of the [[NBC]] peacock logo is seen spreading its feathers. ==Reception== In 2006, [[IGN]].com ranked this episode as the series' twelfth best, with "Anthology of Interest I" at number 13, in their list of the "Top 25 Futurama episodes".{{cite web|url=http://tv.ign.com/articles/716/716663p1.html |title=Top 25 Futurama Episodes |author=Iverson, Dan |publisher=IGN.com |date=2006-07-07 |accessdate=2008-03-22 |work= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070706054922/http://tv.ign.com/articles/716/716663p1.html |archivedate=2007-07-06 }} Zack Handlen of ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' gave the episode a B.{{Cite news|url=http://www.avclub.com/tvclub/futurama-roswell-ends-wellanthology-interest-ii-220014|title=Futurama: “Roswell That Ends Well”/“Anthology Of Interest II”|date=2015-05-28|access-date=2017-02-16}} In its initial airing, the episode received a [[Nielsen rating]] of 4.5, placing it 62nd among primetime shows for the week of December 31, 2001 – January 6, 2002.{{cite news | title = Bowl games give ABC rare touchdown in Nielsen ratings | url = http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-15624083.html | work = Daily Breeze | author = Moore, Frazier | publisher = Copley Press Inc. | accessdate = 2009-03-07 | date = 2002-01-09 }} ==See also== *[[Pixels (2015 film)|''Pixels'' (2015 film)]], a film with a storyline similar to "Raiders of the Lost Arcade" ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{wikiquote|Futurama#Anthology of Interest II|Anthology of Interest II}} *[[infosphere:Anthology of Interest II|Anthology of Interest II]] at [[infosphere:|The Infosphere]]. *{{IMDb episode|0756879}} *{{Tv.com episode|107891}} {{Futurama episodes|3}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Anthology Of Interest Ii}} [[Category:Futurama (season 3) episodes]] [[Category:2002 American television episodes]] [[Category:Works about video games]] [[Category:The Wizard of Oz (1939 film)]] [[Category:Television episodes written by David X. Cohen]]

'''Barbara Cox''' is a writer and script editor, mainly in British television, who has worked on such programmes as ''[[The Bill]]'', ''[[The Paradise Club]]'', ''[[Cardiac Arrest (TV series)|Cardiac Arrest]]'', ''[[Love Hurts]]'', ''[[Dangerfield (TV series)|Dangerfield]]'' and ''[[Holby City]]''.
In 1993/4 Cox collaborated with playwright [[Terry Johnson (dramatist)|Terry Johnson]] to create the thriller series '' [[99-1]] '' ([[Zenith Productions]]/ITV), which starred [[Leslie Grantham]] and [[Sir Robert Stephens]]. ''99-1'' did well in its first season with ratings of 12 million, but was eclipsed in its second year when the BBC scheduled ''[[The X Files]]'' against it; a projected third series was not commissioned. Cox went on to edit the more mainstream and solidly successful ''[[Wycliffe (TV series)|Wycliffe]]''.
More recently she has also been involved in children's programmes including ''[[I Was a Rat]] '', ''[[Bootleg (miniseries)|Bootleg]]'' and the multi-award-winning adaptation of [[Malorie Blackman]]'s novel '' [[Pig Heart Boy]] ''.
In 2005, Barbara Cox won a [[BAFTA|British Academy Children's Film and Television Award]] for Writer, Best Adapted Script, for the children's drama ''Wipe Out'' based on a book by [[Mimi Thebo]].
==External links== * {{IMDb name|0184918}} * [http://www.bafta.org.uk BAFTA homepage]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Cox, Barbara}} [[Category:British television writers]] [[Category:Women television writers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Place of birth missing (living people)]]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Childbirth]]; added [[Category:Books and art about childbirth]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''Birth in Four Cultures: A Crosscultural Investigation of Childbirth in Yucatan, Holland, Sweden, and the United States''''' is an anthropological study of childbirth by [[Brigitte Jordan]] published in 1978.
== Background == Throughout the book Jordan explores the birth practices of four different cultures: the [[Yucatán|Yucatan]], [[Holland]], [[Sweden]], and the [[United States]]. In chapter four, she explains in detail why she decided to focus her study on childbirth: "I never chose to study birth. In some sense, birth chose me."<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title=Birth in Four Cultures|last=Jordan|first=Brigitte|publisher=Waveland Press, Inc.|year=1993|isbn=0-88133-717-X|location=|pages=93|quote=I never chose to study birth. In some sense, birth chose me}}</ref>
==Concept== Jordan's work argues against romanticized perspectives of "early, less complex societies"<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Burtch|first=Brian E.|date=1981-01-01|title=Review of Birth in Four Cultures: A Crosscultural Investigation of Childbirth in Yucatan, Holland, Sweden and the United States|jstor=3340150|journal=The Canadian Journal of Sociology / Cahiers canadiens de sociologie|volume=6|issue=4|pages=547–549|doi=10.2307/3340150}}</ref> that present childbirth as uncomplicated. Instead, she suggests that childbirth is a life-altering event in all societies, but can be understood differently by using a [[cross-cultural]] perspective.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.com/Birth-Four-Cultures-Crosscultural-Investigation/dp/088133717X/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1486655147&sr=8-1&keywords=birth+in+four+cultures|title=Birth in Four Cultures : A Crosscultural Investigation of Childbirth in Yucatan, Holland, Sweden, and the United States|last=Jordan|first=Brigitte|last2=Davis-Floyd|first2=Robbie|date=1992-11-01|publisher=Waveland Pr Inc|isbn=9780881337174|edition=4th|language=English}}</ref> In their edited collection, ''Childbirth and Authoritative Knowledge: Cross-Cultural Perspectives'', [[Robbie Davis-Floyd|Robbie E. Davis-Floyd]] and [[Carolyn Sargent|Carolyn F. Sargent]] praised the book for focusing "anthropological attention on childbirth as a subject worthy of in-depth ethnographic fieldwork and cross-cultural comparison, and that inspired many others to enter the field."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Davis-Floyd|first1=Robbie E.|last2=Sargent|first2=Carolyn F.|title=Childbirth and Authoritative Knowledge: Cross-Cultural Perspectives|date=1997|publisher=University of California Press|location=Berkeley|isbn=0520207858|page=2}}</ref>
Jordan argues that birth should be examined utilizing a biosocial approach, which recognizes birth as a biological process that is shaped by social and cultural practices.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Birth in Four Cultures: A Cross Cultural Investigation of Childbirth in Yucatan, Holland, Sweden, and the United States|last=Jordan|first=Brigitte|publisher=Waveland Press, Inc.|year=1993|isbn=9780881337174|editor-last=Davis-Floyd|editor-first=Robbie|location=Long Grove, IL|pages=xv-xvi|quote=}}</ref> Along with a concern for medical safety, Jordan also focuses on "maternal attitudes and participation in birth, the birth setting, and the mother's selection of birth attendants."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Martin|first=Ronald|year=1980|title=Birth in Four Cultures|url=|journal=The Journal of Nervous and Mental Disease|volume=168|pages=386–387|via=}}</ref> Jordan uses her observations in the field, alongside academic anthropological sources to analyze birth as it occurs in four different societies.<ref name=":1" />
== Field method == As an ethnographer, Jordan and her collaborator Nancy Fuller incorporated qualitative and quantitative approaches to compare health policies and statistical data from the four birthing systems.<ref>{{cite journal|jstor=648585|title=Reviewed Work: Birth in Four Cultures: A Cross-Cultural Investigation of Childbirth in Yucatan, Holland, Sweden, and the United States by Brigitte Jordan|last=MacCormack|first=Carol|date=|website=}}</ref> Jordan employed formal and informal interviews based on her [[participant observation]]. In particular, she used technological means of data collection, such as videotaping and tape recording devices, to record and review her findings and produce high-quality documentation.<ref name=":0" /> Jordan reflects upon the methodological and ethical responsibility in her research to justify the decision-making process of the biosocial framework.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZArPH0nFGo0C&pg=PA233&lpg=PA233&dq=brigitte+jordan+and+interviewing+in+birth+of+four+cultures+4th+edition&source=bl&ots=Kly05PRli-&sig=I0qpb5Z0wky8BCG6cfJYVWd884w&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjT6-zPwIHSAhUM0oMKHZ2QAQoQ6AEIQTAG#v=onepage&q=brigitte%20jordan%20and%20interviewing%20in%20birth%20of%20four%20cultures%204th%20edition&f=false|title=Studies in Human Sexuality: A Selected Guide|last=Frayser|first=Suzanne|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Reception and recognition ==
=== Honors and awards === In 1980, Jordan received the [[Margaret Mead Award]] in recognition for ''Birth in Four Cultures''.<ref name=":1" />
=== Academic reviews === While much of the reception for ''Birth in Four Cultures'' has been overwhelmingly positive, some anthropologists have criticized Jordan for her exclusive focus on the social aspects of birth without much attention to religious or ideological concerns in her research.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Austin|first=Martha A.|date=1979-01-01|title=Review of Birth in Four Cultures|jstor=648398|journal=Medical Anthropology Newsletter|volume=11|issue=1|pages=21–22}}</ref>
''Birth in Four Cultures'' was one of the first [[Ethnography|ethnographies]] to study cross-cultural systems of birth. Jordan argued that economics, culture, and politics affect birth as a system, which led to the beginning of the sub-category of anthropology called Anthropology of Birth.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://surface.syr.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1000&context=ant|title=Perspectives on the Anthropology of Birth|last=Van Hollen|first=Cecilia|date=1994|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=1994|dead-url=|access-date=February 8, 2017}}</ref>
''Birth in Four Cultures'' has been used to advocate for preserving midwifery care in developing countries.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.midwiferytoday.com/articles/globalissues.asp|title=Anthropological Perspectives on Global Issues in Midwifery|last=Davis-Floyd|first=Robbie|date=2000|website=Midwifery Today|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=February 9, 2017}}</ref>
== Updates and editions == There have been four editions of the book in 1978, 1980, 1983, and 1993, including updates to the material from Jordan's continued research on the subject. The 4th edition was revised and expanded by anthropologist Robbie Davis-Floyd.<ref name=":0" />
== References == <!--- See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes on how to create references using<ref></ref> tags, these references will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
[[Category:1978 books]] [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:Books and art about childbirth]] [[Category:Anthropology books]]

revision.comment: ([[c:GR|GR]]) [[c:COM:FR|File renamed]]: [[File:Blanco y Negro, 06-09-1902, de Lorenzo Coullaut Valera.jpg]] → [[File:1902-09-06, Blanco y Negro, Lorenzo Coullaut Valera.jpg]]
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox magazine | title = Blanco y Negro | image_file = 1902-09-06, Blanco y Negro, Lorenzo Coullaut Valera.jpg | image_size = | image_caption = | editor = | editor_title = | frequency = Weekly | circulation = | category = Literary magazine | company = | publisher = Editorial Catolica | firstdate = 1891 | finaldate = 1988 | country = [[Spain]] | based = [[Madrid]] | language = [[Spanish language|Spanish]] | website = | issn = }}
'''''Blanco y Negro''''' (meaning ''Black and White'' in English)<ref name="RosHazbun2014">{{cite book|author1=Xon de Ros|author2=Geraldine Hazbun|title=A Companion to Spanish Women's Studies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pRYABQAAQBAJ&pg=PA195|accessdate=27 November 2014|date=1 September 2014|publisher=Boydell & Brewer Ltd|isbn=978-1-85566-286-5|page=195}}</ref> was a Spanish-language weekly art and literary magazine and later, the companion of the daily ''[[ABC (newspaper)|ABC]]''.<ref name="Crow2005">{{cite book|author=John Armstrong Crow|title=Spain: The Root and the Flower : an Interpretation of Spain and the Spanish People|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g2NKy8QCxw4C&pg=PA410|accessdate=27 November 2014|year=2005|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-24496-2|page=410}}</ref> The magazine was published in [[Madrid]], [[Spain]].
==History and profile== ''Blanco y Negro'' was established in 1891.<ref name=RosHazbun2014/><ref name=rg>{{cite web|title=Blanco y Negro|url=http://www.reportersgrafics.net/en/publicacions/blanco-y-negro|work=Reporters Grafics|accessdate=7 April 2015}}</ref> The title of the magazine was a reference to the contrasts in life such as laughter and tears and the sad and happy.<ref name=Charnon-Deutsch2010/> Its founder was Torcuato Luca de Tena.<ref name=rg/> The magazine was controlled by the [[Catholic Church]] through Editorial Catolica which also published it on a weekly basis.<ref name=RosHazbun2014/><ref>{{cite book|author1=Christopher Ross|author2=Bill Richardson|author3=Begoña Sangrador-Vegas|title=Contemporary Spain Third Edition|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YWbYAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA267|accessdate=30 November 2014|date=28 October 2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-4441-1699-1|page=267}}</ref> The headquarters of the weekly was in Madrid.<ref name=rg/>
''Blanco y Negro'' employed color print, paper couché and advanced image printing techniques such as [[photoengraving]] and [[photogravure]] for the first time in Spain. In addition, it published the first [[color photo]] in the country on 15 May 1912.<ref name=rg/> The magazine covered the articles of various Spanish writers and caricaturists, including [[Cecilio Pla]], Ramon Cilla among the others.<ref name="Charnon-Deutsch2010">{{cite book|author=Lou Charnon-Deutsch|title=Fictions of the Feminine in the Nineteenth-Century Spanish Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YNpRo2TOhjoC&pg=PA263|accessdate=27 November 2014|date=1 November 2010|publisher=Penn State Press|isbn=0-271-04240-0|page=263}}</ref> The weekly also published articles by [[Hilda de Toledano]] (literary pseudonym of [[Maria Pia of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha Braganza]]), a writer and famous pretender to the throne of [[Portugal]].
In 1988 ''Blanco y Negro'' became a Sunday supplement to the daily newspaper ''[[ABC (newspaper)|ABC]]''. In 2005, it was renamed ''ABCD Las Artes y Las Letras'' and continues as a weekly supplement.
==See also== * [[List of magazines in Spain]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

page.title: Born on the Fourth of July

revision.text:
{{For|the film|Born on the Fourth of July (film)}} {{italic title}} [[File:Ron Kovic - Born On The Fourth Of July.jpeg|thumb|200px|right]] '''''Born on the Fourth of July''''', published in 1976, is the best-selling [[autobiography]] by [[Ron Kovic]], a paralyzed [[Vietnam War]] veteran who became an [[anti-war]] activist. Kovic was born on July 4, 1946, and his book's ironic title echoed a famous line from [[George M. Cohan]]'s patriotic 1904 song, "[[The Yankee Doodle Boy]]" (also known as "Yankee Doodle Dandy"). The book was adapted into a 1989 Academy Award winning [[Born on the Fourth of July (film)|film of the same name]] co-written by [[Oliver Stone]] and Ron Kovic, starring [[Tom Cruise]] as Kovic.
==Origin== ''Born on the Fourth of July'' was written in [[Santa Monica, California]], during the fall of 1974 in exactly one month, three weeks and two days.<ref name="kovicweb">[http://pej.org/html/print.php?sid=2718 Born on the Fourth of July: The Long Journey Home] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927030105/http://pej.org/html/print.php?sid=2718 |date=September 27, 2007 }} Ron Kovic – accessed on 8 August 2005</ref> It tells the story of Kovic's life growing up in [[Massapequa, New York]], joining the United States [[United States Marines|Marine Corps]] right out of high school, going to Vietnam for two tours of duty, getting shot, finding himself paralyzed and in need of a wheelchair, and eventually starting a new life as a peace activist.
{{quote|I wrote all night long, seven days a week, single space, no paragraphs, front and back of the pages, pounding the keys so hard the tips of my fingers would hurt. I couldn't stop writing, and I remember feeling more alive than I had ever felt. Convinced that I was destined to die young, I struggled to leave something of meaning behind, to rise above the darkness and despair. I wanted people to understand. I wanted to share with them as nakedly and openly and intimately as possible what I had gone through, what I had endured. I wanted them to know what it really meant to be in a war — to be shot and wounded, to be fighting for my life on the intensive care ward — not the myth we had grown up believing. I wanted people to know about the hospitals and the enema room, about why I had become opposed to the war, why I had grown more and more committed to peace and nonviolence.|Ron Kovic, on writing his autobiography.<ref name="kovicweb" />}}
==Differences from the film adaptation==
* Ron Kovic is shown to have confessed his supposed role in the Marine Corporal's accidental death to the deceased man's sympathetic parents and widow, who admits that she cannot find it in her heart to forgive him, but God might do so. In reality, this meeting never happened, but director Stone admits this was done to add to the inner conflict Kovic was going through and to give him some closure.<ref>''Born on the Fourth of July audio commentary''</ref> * [[Kyra Sedgwick]]'s character of Donna, Ron's on-screen high school sweetheart, never existed and did not inspire him to become an anti-war activist. The film portrays Kovic watching her protest after the [[Kent State Shootings]] and get beaten up by police. Although Kovic did not witness the protest in person, he nevertheless did watch the event on television, and the memoir states that he was outraged by the treatment of the protestors, much like his feelings towards the treatment of his fellow veterans.<ref>''Born on the Fourth of July'', p. 178</ref>
==Cultural references== *[[Bruce Springsteen]] dedicated his 1978 performance of "[[Darkness on the Edge of Town]]" live at [[Winterland]] to Kovic, saying that he read ''Born on the Fourth of July'', and "loved the book a whole lot". He frequently mentions the book, and his chance meeting with Kovic, before playing his song "[[Born in the U.S.A. (song)#Track listing|Shut Out the Light]]". *Folk musician [[Tom Paxton]] adapted the book into a song of the same title on his 1977 album ''New Songs from the Briarpatch'', and met Kovic backstage at the Bottom Line Club in New York City the same year. *American punk rock band [[Green Day]] references the title of the film in their 2009 song "[[21st Century Breakdown (song)|21st Century Breakdown]]". * American punk rock band [[The Gaslight Anthem]] references the title of the film in their 2014 song "Rollin' and Tumblin'" on the album ''[[Get Hurt (album)|Get Hurt]]''. * British singer [[Ed Sheeran]] references the title of the film in his rap verse in [[Taylor Swift]]'s 2017 song "[[End Game (Taylor Swift song)|End Game]]".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://ew.com/music/2018/02/09/taylor-swift-ed-sheeran-new-behind-the-scenes-video/|title=Taylor Swift and Ed Sheeran reveal the romantic inspiration for his 'End Game' rap|last=Carr|first=Mary Kate|work=EW|date=February 9, 2018|access-date=February 12, 2018}}</ref>
==See also== *[[July 4#Births|Births on July 4th]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:1976 books]] [[Category:American autobiographies]] [[Category:Books adapted into films]] [[Category:McGraw-Hill books]] [[Category:Non-fiction books about the United States Marine Corps]] [[Category:Vietnam War books]]

revision.text:
{{more footnotes|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox building | name = Bursledon Brickworks Industrial Museum | native_name = | former_names = Hooper & Ashby (1897–1903)
The Bursledon Brick Co. Limited (1903–1959)
The Sussex & Dorking Brick Company (year unknown)
Redland Holdings Ltd. (1959–1974)
Bursledon Brickworks Conservation Centre (1995/96–2000s)
Bursledon Brickworks Industrial Museum (2012–2017)
The Brickworks Museum (2017–) | alternate_names = | image = Bursledon Brickworks Chimney.jpg | caption = | location = [[Swanwick, Hampshire|Swanwick]], [[Hampshire]], England | address = Coal Park Lane / Swanwick Lane | location_town = Southampton | location_country = England | coordinates = {{coord|50.8858|-1.2908|type:landmark_region:GB|display=inline,title}} | start_date = | completion_date = | demolition_date = | destruction_date = | architect = | owner = Hampshire Buildings Preservation Trust | cost = | floor_area = | floor_count = 2 | awards = Solent Protection Society 2004 Conservation Award{{Cite web|url=http://www.solentprotection.org/about-us/conservation-awards/|title=Conservation Awards|last=|first=|date=|website=www.solentprotection.org|publisher=Solent Protection Society|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=9 April 2017}}
Tourism South East / Beautiful South Business Awards: Best Community Tourism Business 2014{{Cite web|url=http://www.dailyecho.co.uk/news/11649905.display/|title=Top tourist attractions sweep to victory at industry awards ceremony|website=Daily Echo|language=en|access-date=10 April 2017}}
Small Visitor Attraction of the Year (Bronze) 2014, 2017 (Silver)
IMECH Industrial Heritage Award
[[TripAdvisor]] Certificate of Excellence 2015, 2016
Fareham In Bloom: Business Parks and Commercial Landscape (Silver) 2018
Wildlife Garden (Silver Gilt) 2018 | references = | map_type = | map_alt = | map_caption = | altitude = 11 metres | building_type = Museum | architectural_style = [[Victorian architecture|Victorian]] | structural_system = | renovation_date = | height = | architecture_firm = | structural_engineer = | services_engineer = | civil_engineer = | main_contractor = | url = [https://www.bursledonbrickworks.org.uk/ www.bursledonbrickworks.org.uk] | alt = | type = | longs = | diameter = }} '''Bursledon Brickworks Industrial Museum''', often shortened to '''Bursledon Brickworks''' is a volunteer-run [[brickworks]] [[museum]] based in the village of [[Swanwick, Hampshire|Swanwick]], [[Hampshire]], England. It is thought to be the last Victorian steam-driven brickworks left in the [[United Kingdom|UK]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.fareham.gov.uk/leisure/discover_fareham/bbrickworks.aspx|title=Bursledon Brickworks|last=Info|first=Webmaster|date=|website=www.fareham.gov.uk|publisher=Fareham Borough Council|access-date=7 December 2016}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.erih.net/i-want-to-go-there/site/show/bursledon-brickworks-industrial-museum/|title=ERIH: Bursledon Brickworks Industrial Museum|last=|first=|date=|work=www.erih.net|access-date=7 December 2016|via=}} The brick kiln, chimney, drying sheds, and the boiler and engine house at the south section of the brickworks are [[Listed building#England and Wales|listed Grade II*]] as a group on the [[National Heritage List for England]].{{NHLE|num=1233725|desc=Brick kiln, chimney, drying sheds, boiler and engine house at Bursledon Brickworks|access-date=11 March 2018|mode=cs2}} ==History== ===Edward Hooper=== Bursledon Brickworks started out in 1897 as ''Hooper & Ashby'', a [[Southampton]]-based builders' merchants, who also made bricks. The company was co-founded by the Ashby's and the Hooper's two separate [[Quakers|Quaker]] families, both hailing from the town of [[Staines-upon-Thames|Staines]] in [[Middlesex]] (now part of the county of [[Surrey]]). Edward Hooper, who moved to Southampton at the age of 26 was a civil engineer and architect. In the 1851 census records, Edward is described as being both an engineer and a brick maker. He takes out a lease on Baltic Wharf in Chapel Road. It is here that Edward sets up a business as a builders' merchant and a manufacturer trading in slate. This is followed by the expansion of his business, when he takes out a lease on a second building, American Wharf, nine-years later.{{Cite book|title=THE BRICKWORKS MUSEUM AT BURSLEDON A HISTORY AND GUIDE|last=|first=|publisher=Hampshire Buildings Preservation Trust|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}} ===Hooper & Ashby=== In 1903, ''Hooper & Ashby'' changed its name to ''The Bursledon Brick Co. Limited'' or ''(B.B.C. Ltd.),'' this coincided with the extension of the southern complex with the addition of the northern complex. This was further extended in 1935. With the extra capacity, the brickworks was producing in excess of 20 million bricks a year. They were one of the main producers of bricks in the region.{{cite web | url=http://www.bursledonbrickworks.org.uk/page.php?pageid=15 | title=The History | publisher=Bursledon Brickworks | work=www.bursledonbrickworks.org.uk | accessdate=19 September 2016}} Most of the original machinery was moved to the Swanwick site from Chandler's Ford. ==Sport== {{Expand section|date=March 2017}} On 20 March, Bursledon Brickworks F.C. beat [[North Warnborough]] 4–1 in the semi-finals of the 1926 Hants Junior Cup.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nwcfsa.co.uk/centenary/|title=North Warnborough F.C. 1895-1995 (A Centenary Tribute by Anne Pitcher MBA)|last=Pitcher|first=Anne|date=|website=www.nwcfsa.co.uk|publisher=North Warnborough F.C.|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=3 February 2017}} The cricket team, Lower Swanwick B.C.C. won the Sarisbury and District Cricket League Division 2 championship shield. ==Post-war period== {{Expand section|date=March 2017}} After the [[World War II|Second World War]], the family business was amalgamated with the Sussex and Dorking Brick Company and in 1959 became [[Redland plc|Redland Holdings Ltd.]] ==Closure of the brickworks== The brickworks finally closed in 1974, and the site was later saved from demolition by the ''Hampshire Buildings Preservation Trust''. The south section of Bursledon Brickworks which houses the brick kiln, chimney, drying sheds, boiler and engine house are [[Listed building#Grade II|Grade II*]] listed.{{Cite web|url=https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1233725|title=BRICK KILN, CHIMNEY, DRYING SHEDS, BOILER AND ENGINE HOUSE AT BURSLEDON BRICKWORKS SOUTH SECTION|last=|first=|date=|website=Historic England|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=22 March 2017}} The north section was demolished and the land was acquired by the [[NATS Holdings|National Air Traffic Services]]. ''NATS'' operate the [[London Area Control Centre]] and [[London Terminal Control Centre]]. As site owners, they have provided funding for the [[Swanwick, Hampshire|Swanwick]] Lakes Wildlife Reserve project managed by the [[Hampshire and Isle of Wight Wildlife Trust]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.fareham.gov.uk/leisure/discover_fareham/swanwicklake.aspx|title=Swanwick Lakes Wildlife Reserve|last=|first=|date=|website=www.fareham.gov.uk|publisher=Fareham Borough Council|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=26 March 2017}} ==Charity status== The Bursledon Brickworks Trust which ran from July 1997 – February 2007 was replaced by the Bursledon Brickworks Museum Trust in November 2016.{{Cite web|url=http://apps.charitycommission.gov.uk/Showcharity/RegisterOfCharities/CharityFramework.aspx?RegisteredCharityNumber=1170043&SubsidiaryNumber=0|title=BURSLEDON BRICKWORKS MUSEUM TRUST|last=|first=|date=|website=apps.charitycommission.gov.uk|publisher=Charity Commission|access-date=8 December 2016}} ==As a museum== In 2012, the [[Heritage Lottery Fund]] granted the museum funding of £666,300{{Cite web|url=http://www.dailyecho.co.uk/news/9993087.Brickworks____666_000_bonanza/?ref=rss|title=Bursledon Brickworks £666,000 lottery bonanza|last=Phillips|first=Bethan|date=18 October 2012|website=www.dailyecho.co.uk/news|publisher=''Southern Daily Echo''|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=27 March 2017}} to open up the first floor of the building, create two more education spaces and employ some paid staff. Project manager Carolyne Haynes said: “We’re always under threat, in that it’s a big building that’s permanently trying to fall down and we’re permanently trying to keep it open, running it with volunteers. The most important thing about this money is we’ll be able to pay some staff to make sure we can open three days a week – that will give us a regular opening time. “The place deserves to be recognised nationally and this is a big first step towards that.” The grant will also help pay for improved disabled access for the museum, in Coal Park Lane, Swanwick. Head of the South-East’s Heritage Lottery Fund, Stuart McLeod, said: “Our industrial heritage is something we should be hugely proud of – it helped build the world we live in today. Bursledon Brickworks is the perfect example of this and an incredible survivor of its time.” ==Collections== At the heart of the museum, and the heart of the collection, is the original brick making machinery, steam engine and related smaller equipment, such as barrows, shovels and wagons, once used at Bursledon Brickworks. The steam engine and machinery were restored about 20 years ago and are operated on special events.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bursledonbrickworks.org.uk/collections|title=Collections|last=|first=|date=|website=www.bursledonbrickworks.org.uk|publisher=Bursledon Brickworks|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=5 April 2017}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.strollingguides.co.uk/books/hampshire/places/brickworks.php|title=Bursledon Brickworks Industrial Museum|last=Houghton|first=Anthony|date=|website=www.strollingguides.co.uk/books/hampshire/places/brickworks.php|publisher=Strolling Guides|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=5 April 2017}} ==Entrance to and from the site== [[File:Coal_Park_Lane_sign.jpg|thumb|250x250px|Coal Park Lane entrance in February 2017]] The brickworks has two entrances to the site, the first on Swanwick Lane. This entrance is used by the general public and has a car park. This is also where coaches drop off passengers (group visits) and the rear entrance on Coal Park Lane. The Coal Park Lane entrance is mainly used by the staff and/or volunteers based at the site, and is where deliveries are overseen. ==Radio and television== Back in July 2015, [[BBC Radio Solent]] presenter [[Nick Girdler]] visited the brickworks. Here he oversaw the unveiling of a new brick sculpture, affectionately known as ''the Twisted Shard''. The structure which took 5 months to build was designed by local brick lecturer and artist Joe Taylor from [[Woolston, Southampton]], in partnership with [[Michelmersh|Michelmersh Brick Holdings]]. He enlisted the help of some of his [[Southampton City College]] students to aid in the construction of ''the Twisted Shard''.{{Cite web|url=http://www.dailyecho.co.uk/leisure/news/13424506.Brickie_s_artwork_to_be_unveiled_at_festival/|title=Brickie's artwork to be unveiled at festival|last=|first=|date=16 July 2015|website=www.dailyecho.co.uk/leisure|publisher=''[[Southern Daily Echo]]''|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=4 February 2017}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.mbhplc.co.uk/twisted-shard-multi-sensory-brick-design|title=The Twisted Shard a multi-sensory brick design|last=|first=|date=22 June 2015|website=www.mbhplc.co.uk|publisher=Michelmersh Brick Holdings PLC|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=16 February 2017}}{{Cite web|url=http://jtaylorbuild.com/index.php/projects/|title=Projects|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=J Taylor Brickwork & Building Contractors|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=1 March 2017}} Later that same year, the brickworks was featured in the last five minutes of the [[South Today|BBC]]'s – ''VE Day: First Days of Peace'' documentary.{{Cite tweet |user=BursledonBrickW|author=Bursledon Brickworks|number=598771182549217280|date=14 May 2015|title=Bursledon Brickworks on Twitter: We are in the last five minutes of BBC - VE day #ManorFarmCP and #MilestonesHCT}} In January 2017, a five-minute segment on Bursledon Brickworks featured on Series 14: Episode 6 of the [[BBC One]] television programme [[Antiques Road Trip]].{{Cite web| url=http://www.bursledonbrickworks.org.uk/venue | title=Venue Hire | website=www.bursledonbrickworks.org.uk | publisher=The Brickworks Industrial Museum | access-date=11 January 2017 }} A month later, the museum welcomed [[Wine tasting|wine connoisseur]] [[Master of Wine|Peter Richards]] from [[Saturday Kitchen]].{{Cite tweet |user=wineschools|author=Peter Richards MW|number=827790512505634818|date=4 February 2017|title=On today's @SaturdayKitchen I get excited about bricks. And wine.}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [https://www.bursledonbrickworks.org.uk/ Bursledon Brickworks] - official site * Bursledon Brickworks at [http://www.hampshirebuildings.org.uk/news.htm Hampshire Buildings Preservation Trust] * The Brickworks at [http://www.britishlistedbuildings.co.uk/england/hampshire/swanwick#.V9_ZUYWcFZU/ British Listed Buildings] * Bursledon Brickworks Museum Trust at [https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/09649512/ Companies House] [[Category:Borough of Fareham]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Hampshire]] [[Category:Local museums in Hampshire]] [[Category:Industry museums in England]] [[Category:Steam museums in England]] [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:Private companies limited by guarantee of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Building materials companies of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Companies formerly listed on the London Stock Exchange]] [[Category:Brickworks in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Grade II* listed buildings in Hampshire]] [[Category:Grade II* listed industrial buildings]] [[Category:1897 establishments in England]] [[Category:1974 disestablishments in England]] [[Category:Museums established in 2012]] [[Category:Museums established in the 2010s]] [[Category:Historic buildings and structures in England]] [[Category:National Heritage List for England]] [[Category:Arts centres]] [[Category:Arts centres in England]]

{{refimprove|date=May 2017}} '''Chamberlin, Powell and Bon''' was a British firm of architects whose work involved designing the [[Barbican Estate]]. They are considered one of the most important modernist architectural firms in post-war England.
== Formation == The practice was founded in 1952 by [[Geoffrey Powell|Geoffry Powell]] (1920–1999), [[Peter "Joe" Chamberlin]] (1919–1978) and [[Christoph Bon]] (1921–1999), following Powell's win in the 1951 architectural competition for the [[Golden Lane Estate]]. The three founding partners taught at Kingston Polytechnic (now [[Kingston University]] School of Architecture) when they each entered the design competition with the agreement that should any of them win they would form a partnership with the other two to deliver the project. The Golden Lane Estate is sometimes referred to as the apprentice piece of the practice and is important for its planned landscape which 'straddles the boundary between the picturesque and the formal'.<ref>[Chamberlin, Powell and Bon, Elain Harwood (foreword by [[Piers Gough]]), RIBA Publishing / [[Twentieth Century Society]], London 2011, {{ISBN|978-1-85946-397-0}}]page 38</ref>
Charles Greenberg became an additional partner of the practice in 1960, although he chose not to add his name to the partnership for personal reasons. He was the only other partner working with CP&B on Barbican. Frank Woods also became an additional partner, and in 1985 the firm name became '''Chamberlin Powell Bon & Woods'''.<ref>[http://www.barbicanliving.co.uk/d10a.html Barbican Living: Chamberlin Powell and Bon] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091219051830/http://www.barbicanliving.co.uk/d10a.html |date=December 19, 2009}}, Barbican Living</ref> The firm continued to 1989. Its records are archived at the [[Royal Institute of British Architects]].<ref name="records">{{cite web |url=http://discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/details/r/N13577930 |title=company archive incl drawings, perspectives, models, photographs, reports, project... |publisher=[[The National Archives (United Kingdom)|National Archives of the United Kingdom]] |accessdate=January 15, 2018}}</ref>
== Main work == Following completion of the [[Golden Lane Estate]], they won the commission to design and execute the adjacent [[Barbican Estate|Barbican]] development, also for the Corporation of the [[City of London]], the wealthy municipal administration that has responsibility for the historic core of London, today the central business district. The Barbican was such a large job they set up a sub-practice to deal with it: Chamberlin Powell and Bon (Barbican) Ltd.
The firm was strongly influenced by the work and ideas of Swiss/French architect [[Le Corbusier]],{{citation needed|date=October 2014}} with the essence of the innovative design being encapsulated by the project architect Leopold Rubinstein who trained with Le Corbusier in Paris.{{citation needed|date=October 2014}} Other works included two schools in London, [[New Hall, Cambridge]] (a new college at [[Cambridge University]]) now known as Murray Edwards College, and an ambitious materplan and major expansion of the campus at [[University of Leeds]].
It is a measure of the importance of the practice in post-war British architecture that many of their works are now [[Listed Building]]s.
==List of works== [[File:355 Kings Road, Chelsea, London SW3 4 June 2011.jpg|thumb|355 Kings Road, one of several residential designs by CP&B]] *[[Golden Lane Estate]], Aldersgate, London EC1 1952-1961 (Listed GII & G II*) *[[Barbican Estate]], London EC2 (Listed G II) *Vanbrugh Park Estate, Blackheath, London SE3, completed 1963 *Two Saints (later Geoffrey Chaucer) School, Harper Road, London SE1 (Listed II* but partially demolished by [[Southwark]] borough council in 2007 for the creation of [[Globe Academy]]) <ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.c20society.org.uk/casework/geoffrey-chaucer-school-faces-demolition/ |title=Geoffrey Chaucer School faces demolition |date=Jan 2007 |accessdate= 27 July 2016}}</ref> *Development at 355 Kings Road for ILEA *Bousfield Primary School, The Boltons, Earls Court, London SW5 1954–56<ref>[http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=50025 The Boltons and Redcliffe Square area: The area after 1878], British History Online</ref> (Listed GII) *[[University of Leeds]], campus expansion masterplan and many individual buildings (1963–75), the largest collection of buildings by the firm after the Barbican. (Listed G II<ref>{{NHLE|num=1393835|desc=|accessdate=26 June 2015}}</ref> & G II*<ref>{{NHLE|num=1393836|desc=|accessdate=26 June 2015}}</ref>) *[[University of Birmingham]] (1966) *[[Murray Edwards College, Cambridge]] (Formerly New Hall, Cambridge). [[Cambridge University]] a new college for an ancient university (1962–64, Listed G II*). *30a Hendon Avenue, London N3, the only private house designed by the practice (Listed G II) *Of the unrealised works the Zoology Tower for [[Oxford University]], a highly figured {{convert|300|ft|0|abbr=on}} point block which would have been visible all over Oxford. *Of the demolished buildings the most significant is a celebrated Cooper Taber Seed Factory, Witham, Essex and Shipley Salt Grammar School, Shipley, West Yorkshire. *Cheltenham Grammar School, Cheltenham.(1965) These buildings were demolished in 1996 (partially owing to the disintegration of the concrete in the 1980s) and replaced on the site by a new campus for what is now [[Pate's Grammar School]].
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20150725212909/http://www.barbicanliving.co.uk/Barbican_estate_design/d10a.html Chamberlin, Powell & Bon]

{{Use Hong Kong English|date=June 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2014}} {{Infobox film |name = Clans of Intrigue |image = Clans of Intrigue.jpg |caption = DVD cover art | film name = {{Film name|traditional = 楚留香 |simplified = 楚留香}} |director = [[Chor Yuen]] |producer = [[Runme Shaw]] |story = [[Gu Long]] |screenplay = [[Ni Kuang]] |starring = [[Ti Lung]]
Ling Yun
[[Elliot Ngok]]
[[Nora Miao]]
[[Lee Ching]]
[[Betty Pei]] |music = [[Frankie Chan]] |cinematography = Wong Chit |editing = Chiang Hsing-lung |studio = [[Shaw Brothers Studio]] |distributor = Shaw Brothers Studio |released = {{Film date|df=yes|1977|03|05}} |runtime = 95 minutes |country = Hong Kong |language = Mandarin |budget = |gross = }} '''''Clans of Intrigue''''' is a 1977 Hong Kong ''[[wuxia]]'' film adapted from ''Fragrance in the Sea of Blood'' of [[Gu Long]]'s ''[[Chu Liuxiang]]'' novel series. The film was directed by [[Chor Yuen]], produced by the [[Shaw Brothers Studio]], and starred [[Ti Lung]] as the lead character. It was followed by ''[[Legend of the Bat]]'' (1978) and ''[[Perils of the Sentimental Swordsman]]'' (1982). There's a 1993 Hong Kong movie of the same genre and title directed by Chan Muk Chuen and starred Mang Fei and Yang Guan Guan.. ==Plot== Chu Liuxiang is having drinks with his friend, Monk Wuhua. Gong Nanyan of the Holy Water Palace suddenly appears and accuses Chu of having stolen the palace's Heaven's One Holy Water and committed a series of murders. She agrees to give Chu a month's time to clear his name, or else the mistress of the palace will kill him. Chu's curiosity and eagerness to prove his innocence spur him to investigate the case. ==Cast== *[[Ti Lung]] as [[Chu Liuxiang]] *[[Elliot Ngok]] as Monk Wuhua *[[Lee Ching]] as Black Pearl *[[Nora Miao]] as Gong Nanyan *[[Betty Pei]] as Shuimu Yinji *Ling Yun as Zhongyuan Yidianhong *Tin Ching as Nangong Lin *Nancy Yen as Qiu Lingsu *Chan Si-gai as Su Rongrong *Lau Wai-ling as Li Hongxiu *Chong Lee as Song Tian'er *[[Ku Feng]] as Leng Qiuhun *Ku Wen-chung as Abbot Tianfeng *Cheng Miu as Sun Xuepu *Norman Chu as Song Gang *[[Yuen Wah]] as Iga Ninja *Keung Hon *Ku Kuan-chung *Chan Shen *Teresa Ha *Yeung Chi-hing *Shum Lo *Wong Ching-ho *Ng Hong-sang *Liu Wai *Lee Sau-kei *Siu Kam *Ngai Fei *Leung Seung-wan *[[Corey Yuen]] *Wong Pau-gei *Lee Hang *[[Yuen Cheung-yan]] *Chui Fat *Tang Tak-cheung *Hsu Hsia *Wong Chi-keung *San Kuai *Alan Chan *Ting Tung *Ng Yuen-fan *Hung Ling-ling *Lui Hung *Cheung Chok-chow *Mama Hung *Wang Han-chen *Chin Chun *Cheung Sek-au *Cheung Hei *Gam Tin-chue *Tsang Chor-lam *Brandy Yuen *Kong Chuen *Man Man ==External links== *{{IMDb title|id=0075833}} *{{hkmdb title|id=5772}} {{Chu Liuxiang}} {{Chor Yuen}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Clans of Intrigue}} [[Category:1977 films]] [[Category:1977 martial arts films]] [[Category:Hong Kong films]] [[Category:Wuxia films]] [[Category:Hong Kong martial arts films]] [[Category:Hong Kong action thriller films]] [[Category:1970s action thriller films]] [[Category:1970s mystery films]] [[Category:Shaw Brothers Studio films]] [[Category:Mandarin-language films]] [[Category:Works based on Chu Liuxiang (novel series)]] [[Category:Lesbian-related films]] [[Category:Films directed by Chor Yuen]] [[Category:Films based on works by Gu Long]] {{1970s-HongKong-film-stub}}
